title: 107_s1035
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Preservation Act" and includes findings related to the Great Lakes. Congress finds that the Great Lakes are precious public natural resources crucial to the economies of the Great Lakes States, containing 1/5 of the world's fresh water supply and serving as a vital source of safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes are essential for industrial, agricultural, and drinking water purposes. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 governs water diversion in the region. Governors and Premiers make decisions on water usage based on proposals. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 governs water diversion in the region, with decisions on water usage made by the Governors of the Great Lakes States. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 governs water diversion in the region, with decisions on water usage made by the Governors of the Great Lakes States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Bulk fresh water" is fresh water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" refers to water from specific lakes or interconnecting waterways. The term "Lakes basin" refers to water from specific Great Lakes and connecting waterways within the watershed. The term "Great Lake" specifically refers to Lake Erie. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada, and the term "Great Lakes State" is also mentioned. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada, while the term "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. The text chunk discusses a moratorium on the export of bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin, with a provision for it to cease upon approval of a conservation standard by the Governors of the Great Lakes States and the Premiers of the Great Lakes Provinces. The text chunk discusses a moratorium on the export of bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin, with a provision for the Federal Government to enter into an agreement with Canada to abide by the terms of the moratorium until a specified date. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. Congress finds that the Great Lakes have played a significant role in the history of settlement, commerce, and recreation in the Great Lakes States. Lighthouses in these states have been crucial for navigation and hold historical and architectural importance. However, many lighthouses are in poor condition due to neglect, putting their future at risk. The Great Lakes lighthouses have historical and architectural significance, but many are in poor condition due to neglect. The Secretary will conduct a study to identify options for preserving these lighthouses within 3 years. The Secretary will conduct a study to review programs and consult with various organizations to preserve the lighthouses in the Great Lakes States. The Secretary will consult with state and local historical associations, preservation agencies, the Coast Guard Commandant, and other relevant entities in the Great Lakes States. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose.
